content: The Act of 2008 establishes the Commission on the Conflict between Russia and Georgia to examine the causes of the conflict and make policy recommendations towards the countries involved. The Commission on the Conflict between Russia and Georgia is composed of 9 members appointed by various leaders from the Senate and House of Representatives. Members should be prominent US citizens with expertise in foreign relations and relations between Russia and Georgia. The Commission on the Conflict between Russia and Georgia consists of 9 members appointed within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. The Commission will meet after the 90-day period and a quorum of six members is required for meetings. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission on the Conflict between Russia and Georgia consists of 9 members appointed within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. A quorum of six members is required for meetings, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission on the Conflict between Russia and Georgia will examine the timeline of events since 1991, policies of Russia and Georgia, NATO's role, and US policies related to the conflict. The Commission on the Conflict between Russia and Georgia will review communications between US officials and the Government of Georgia, the role of Russian peacekeepers in South Ossetia, military training and preparedness of Russia and Georgia, allegations of genocide and ethnic cleansing, and make recommendations on US policies towards Russia, Georgia, and other countries in the region. This includes countries in the region in the context of the conflict between Russia and Georgia. This includes countries in the region in the context of the conflict between Russia and Georgia. SEC. 6. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission or any subcommittee may hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, and administer oaths as needed. The Commission can enter into contracts to fulfill its duties and appoint necessary staff without regard to certain rules. The Commission can appoint staff and the executive director as federal employees under specific regulations. The Commission can appoint staff and an executive director as federal employees under specific regulations. Members of the Commission are not subject to certain rules. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement and retain their rights. The Commission can procure consultant services and emphasize hiring individuals with security clearances. The Commission is authorized to obtain information directly from federal agencies to fulfill the purposes of the Act. Federal agencies must provide information, suggestions, estimates, and statistics to the Commission upon request. The Commission and its staff must handle information in accordance with laws and regulations. The General Services Administration provides administrative support to the Commission, and other federal agencies may offer additional services and support as needed and authorized by law. The Commission may accept gifts, use postal services, and make determinations as authorized by law. The Commission is not subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. It will hold public meetings, hearings, and release public versions of reports. Public hearings will protect sensitive information as required by law. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within 180 days of its appointment. The Commission and the provisions of the Act will terminate 60 days after the final report is submitted. The Commission may use this period to conclude its activities and disseminate the final report. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the activities of the Commission until its termination. Amounts appropriated will remain available until the Commission concludes its activities.
